entries.name: strawman
entries.title: strawman
entries.head: You misrepresented someone's argument to make it easier to attack.
entries.first: Misrepresenting someone's argument to make it easier to attack.
entries.description: By exaggerating, misrepresenting, or just completely fabricating someone's argument, it's much easier to present your own position as being reasonable, but this kind of dishonesty serves to undermine honest rational debate.
entries.example: After Will said that we should put more money into health and education, Warren responded by saying that he was surprised that Will hates our country so much that he wants to leave it defenceless by cutting military spending.
entries.pageTitle: Your logical fallacy is strawman
entries.exampleText: Example: After Will said that we should put more money into health and education, Warren responded by saying that he was surprised that Will hates our country so much that he wants to leave it defenceless by cutting military spending.

seo.title: Your logical fallacy is strawman
seo.description: You misrepresented someone's argument to make it easier to attack.

og.og:title: Your logical fallacy is strawman
og.og:description: You misrepresented someone's argument to make it easier to attack.

entries.name: false-cause
entries.title: false cause
entries.head: You presumed that a real or perceived relationship between things means that one is the cause of the other.
entries.first: Presuming that a real or perceived relationship between things means that one is the cause of the other.
entries.description: Many people confuse correlation (things happening together or in sequence) for causation (that one thing actually causes the other to happen). Sometimes correlation is coincidental, or it may be attributable to a common cause.
entries.example: Pointing to a fancy chart, Roger shows how temperatures have been rising over the past few centuries, whilst at the same time the numbers of pirates have been decreasing; thus pirates cool the world and global warming is a hoax.
entries.pageTitle: Your logical fallacy is false cause
entries.exampleText: Example: Pointing to a fancy chart, Roger shows how temperatures have been rising over the past few centuries, whilst at the same time the numbers of pirates have been decreasing; thus pirates cool the world and global warming is a hoax.

seo.title: Your logical fallacy is false cause
seo.description: You presumed that a real or perceived relationship between things means that one is the cause of the other.

og.og:title: Your logical fallacy is false cause
og.og:description: You presumed that a real or perceived relationship between things means that one is the cause of the other.

entries.name: appeal-to-emotion
entries.title: appeal to emotion
entries.head: You attempted to manipulate an emotional response in place of a valid or compelling argument.
entries.first: Manipulating an emotional response in place of a valid or compelling argument.
entries.description: Appeals to emotion include appeals to fear, envy, hatred, pity, pride, and more. It's important to note that sometimes a logically coherent argument may inspire emotion or have an emotional aspect, but the problem and fallacy occurs when emotion is used instead of a logical argument, or to obscure the fact that no compelling rational reason exists for one's position. Everyone, bar sociopaths, is affected by emotion, and so appeals to emotion are a very common and effective argument tactic, but they're ultimately flawed, dishonest, and tend to make one's opponents justifiably emotional.
entries.example: Luke didn't want to eat his sheep's brains with chopped liver and brussel sprouts, but his father told him to think about the poor, starving children in a third world country who weren't fortunate enough to have any food at all.
entries.pageTitle: Your logical fallacy is appeal to emotion
entries.exampleText: Example: Luke didn't want to eat his sheep's brains with chopped liver and brussel sprouts, but his father told him to think about the poor, starving children in a third world country who weren't fortunate enough to have any food at all.

seo.title: Your logical fallacy is appeal to emotion
seo.description: You attempted to manipulate an emotional response in place of a valid or compelling argument.

og.og:title: Your logical fallacy is appeal to emotion
og.og:description: You attempted to manipulate an emotional response in place of a valid or compelling argument.

entries.name: the-fallacy-fallacy
entries.title: the fallacy fallacy
entries.head: You presumed that because a claim has been poorly argued, or a fallacy has been made, that the claim itself must be wrong.
entries.first: Presuming that because a claim has been poorly argued, or a fallacy has been made, that the claim itself must be wrong.
entries.description: It is entirely possible to make a claim that is false yet argue with logical coherency for that claim, just as it is possible to make a claim that is true and justify it with various fallacies and poor arguments.
entries.example: Recognising that Amanda had committed a fallacy in arguing that we should eat healthy food because a nutritionist said it was popular, Alyse said we should therefore eat bacon double cheeseburgers every day.
entries.pageTitle: Your logical fallacy is the fallacy fallacy
entries.exampleText: Example: Recognising that Amanda had committed a fallacy in arguing that we should eat healthy food because a nutritionist said it was popular, Alyse said we should therefore eat bacon double cheeseburgers every day.

seo.title: Your logical fallacy is the fallacy fallacy
seo.description: You presumed that because a claim has been poorly argued, or a fallacy has been made, that the claim itself must be wrong.

og.og:title: Your logical fallacy is the fallacy fallacy
og.og:description: You presumed that because a claim has been poorly argued, or a fallacy has been made, that the claim itself must be wrong.

entries.name: slippery-slope
entries.title: slippery slope
entries.head: You said that if we allow A to happen, then Z will eventually happen too, therefore A should not happen.
entries.first: Asserting that if we allow A to happen, then Z will consequently happen too, therefore A should not happen.
entries.description: The problem with this reasoning is that it avoids engaging with the issue at hand, and instead shifts attention to extreme hypotheticals. Because no proof is presented to show that such extreme hypotheticals will in fact occur, this fallacy has the form of an appeal to emotion fallacy by leveraging fear. In effect the argument at hand is unfairly tainted by unsubstantiated conjecture.
entries.example: Colin Closet asserts that if we allow same-sex couples to marry, then the next thing we know we'll be allowing people to marry their parents, their cars and even monkeys.
entries.pageTitle: Your logical fallacy is slippery slope
entries.exampleText: Example: Colin Closet asserts that if we allow same-sex couples to marry, then the next thing we know we'll be allowing people to marry their parents, their cars and even monkeys.

seo.title: Your logical fallacy is slippery slope
seo.description: You said that if we allow A to happen, then Z will eventually happen too, therefore A should not happen.

og.og:title: Your logical fallacy is slippery slope
og.og:description: You said that if we allow A to happen, then Z will eventually happen too, therefore A should not happen.

entries.name: ad-hominem
entries.title: ad hominem
entries.head: You attacked your opponent's character or personal traits in an attempt to undermine their argument.
entries.first: Attacking your opponent's character or personal traits in an attempt to undermine their argument.
entries.description: Ad hominem attacks can take the form of overtly attacking somebody, or more subtly casting doubt on their character or personal attributes as a way to discredit their argument. The result of an ad hom attack can be to undermine someone's case without actually having to engage with it.
entries.example: After Sally presents an eloquent and compelling case for a more equitable taxation system, Sam asks the audience whether we should believe anything from a woman who isn't married, was once arrested, and smells a bit weird.
entries.pageTitle: Your logical fallacy is ad hominem
entries.exampleText: Example: After Sally presents an eloquent and compelling case for a more equitable taxation system, Sam asks the audience whether we should believe anything from a woman who isn't married, was once arrested, and smells a bit weird.

seo.title: Your logical fallacy is ad hominem
seo.description: You attacked your opponent's character or personal traits in an attempt to undermine their argument.

og.og:title: Your logical fallacy is ad hominem
og.og:description: You attacked your opponent's character or personal traits in an attempt to undermine their argument.

entries.name: tu-quoque
entries.title: tu quoque
entries.head: You avoided having to engage with criticism by turning it back on the accuser - you answered criticism with criticism.
entries.first: Avoiding having to engage with criticism by turning it back on the accuser - answering criticism with criticism.
entries.description: Pronounced too-kwo-kwee. Literally translating as 'you too' this fallacy is also known as the appeal to hypocrisy. It is commonly employed as an effective red herring because it takes the heat off someone having to defend their argument, and instead shifts the focus back on to the person making the criticism.
entries.example: Nicole identified that Hannah had committed a logical fallacy, but instead of addressing the substance of her claim, Hannah accused Nicole of committing a fallacy earlier on in the conversation.
entries.pageTitle: Your logical fallacy is tu quoque
entries.exampleText: Example: Nicole identified that Hannah had committed a logical fallacy, but instead of addressing the substance of her claim, Hannah accused Nicole of committing a fallacy earlier on in the conversation.

seo.title: Your logical fallacy is tu quoque
seo.description: You avoided having to engage with criticism by turning it back on the accuser - you answered criticism with criticism.

og.og:title: Your logical fallacy is tu quoque
og.og:description: You avoided having to engage with criticism by turning it back on the accuser - you answered criticism with criticism.

entries.name: personal-incredulity
entries.title: personal incredulity
entries.head: Because you found something difficult to understand, or are unaware of how it works, you made out like it's probably not true.
entries.first: Saying that because one finds something difficult to understand that it's therefore not true.
entries.description: Complex subjects like biological evolution through natural selection require some amount of understanding before one is able to make an informed judgement about the subject at hand; this fallacy is usually used in place of that understanding.
entries.example: Kirk drew a picture of a fish and a human and with effusive disdain asked Richard if he really thought we were stupid enough to believe that a fish somehow turned into a human through just, like, random things happening over time.
entries.pageTitle: Your logical fallacy is personal incredulity
entries.exampleText: Example: Kirk drew a picture of a fish and a human and with effusive disdain asked Richard if he really thought we were stupid enough to believe that a fish somehow turned into a human through just, like, random things happening over time.

seo.title: Your logical fallacy is personal incredulity
seo.description: Because you found something difficult to understand, or are unaware of how it works, you made out like it's probably not true.

og.og:title: Your logical fallacy is personal incredulity
og.og:description: Because you found something difficult to understand, or are unaware of how it works, you made out like it's probably not true.

entries.name: special-pleading
entries.title: special pleading
entries.head: You moved the goalposts or made up an exception when your claim was shown to be false.
entries.first: Moving the goalposts or making up exceptions when a claim is shown to be false.
entries.description: Humans are funny creatures and have a foolish aversion to being wrong. Rather than appreciate the benefits of being able to change one's mind through better understanding, many will invent ways to cling to old beliefs. One of the most common ways that people do this is to post-rationalize a reason why what they thought to be true must remain to be true. It's usually very easy to find a reason to believe something that suits us, and it requires integrity and genuine honesty with oneself to examine one's own beliefs and motivations without falling into the trap of justifying our existing ways of seeing ourselves and the world around us.
entries.example: Edward Johns claimed to be psychic, but when his 'abilities' were tested under proper scientific conditions, they magically disappeared. Edward explained this saying that one had to have faith in his abilities for them to work.
entries.pageTitle: Your logical fallacy is special pleading
entries.exampleText: Example: Edward Johns claimed to be psychic, but when his 'abilities' were tested under proper scientific conditions, they magically disappeared. Edward explained this saying that one had to have faith in his abilities for them to work.

seo.title: Your logical fallacy is special pleading
seo.description: You moved the goalposts or made up an exception when your claim was shown to be false.

og.og:title: Your logical fallacy is special pleading
og.og:description: You moved the goalposts or made up an exception when your claim was shown to be false.

entries.name: loaded-question
entries.title: loaded question
entries.head: You asked a question that had a presumption built into it so that it couldn't be answered without appearing guilty.
entries.first: Asking a question that has a presumption built into it so that it can't be answered without appearing guilty.
entries.description: Loaded question fallacies are particularly effective at derailing rational debates because of their inflammatory nature - the recipient of the loaded question is compelled to defend themselves and may appear flustered or on the back foot.
entries.example: Grace and Helen were both romantically interested in Brad. One day, with Brad sitting within earshot, Grace asked in an inquisitive tone whether Helen was still having problems with her drug habit.
entries.pageTitle: Your logical fallacy is loaded question
entries.exampleText: Example: Grace and Helen were both romantically interested in Brad. One day, with Brad sitting within earshot, Grace asked in an inquisitive tone whether Helen was still having problems with her drug habit.

seo.title: Your logical fallacy is loaded question
seo.description: You asked a question that had a presumption built into it so that it couldn't be answered without appearing guilty.

og.og:title: Your logical fallacy is loaded question
og.og:description: You asked a question that had a presumption built into it so that it couldn't be answered without appearing guilty.

entries.name: burden-of-proof
entries.title: burden of proof
entries.head: You said that the burden of proof lies not with the person making the claim, but with someone else to disprove.
entries.first: Saying that the burden of proof lies not with the person making the claim, but with someone else to disprove.
entries.description: The burden of proof lies with someone who is making a claim, and is not upon anyone else to disprove. The inability, or disinclination, to disprove a claim does not render that claim valid, nor give it any credence whatsoever. However it is important to note that we can never be certain of anything, and so we must assign value to any claim based on the available evidence, and to dismiss something on the basis that it hasn't been proven beyond all doubt is also fallacious reasoning.
entries.example: Bertrand declares that a teapot is, at this very moment, in orbit around the Sun between the Earth and Mars, and that because no one can prove him wrong, his claim is therefore a valid one.
entries.pageTitle: Your logical fallacy is burden of proof
entries.exampleText: Example: Bertrand declares that a teapot is, at this very moment, in orbit around the Sun between the Earth and Mars, and that because no one can prove him wrong, his claim is therefore a valid one.

seo.title: Your logical fallacy is burden of proof
seo.description: You said that the burden of proof lies not with the person making the claim, but with someone else to disprove.

og.og:title: Your logical fallacy is burden of proof
og.og:description: You said that the burden of proof lies not with the person making the claim, but with someone else to disprove.

entries.name: ambiguity
entries.title: ambiguity
entries.head: You used a double meaning or ambiguity of language to mislead or misrepresent the truth.
entries.first: Using double meanings or ambiguities of language to mislead or misrepresent the truth.
entries.description: Politicians are often guilty of using ambiguity to mislead and will later point to how they were technically not outright lying if they come under scrutiny. The reason that it qualifies as a fallacy is that it is intrinsically misleading.
entries.example: When the judge asked the defendant why he hadn't paid his parking fines, he said that he shouldn't have to pay them because the sign said 'Fine for parking here' and so he naturally presumed that it would be fine to park there.
entries.pageTitle: Your logical fallacy is ambiguity
entries.exampleText: Example: When the judge asked the defendant why he hadn't paid his parking fines, he said that he shouldn't have to pay them because the sign said 'Fine for parking here' and so he naturally presumed that it would be fine to park there.

seo.title: Your logical fallacy is ambiguity
seo.description: You used a double meaning or ambiguity of language to mislead or misrepresent the truth.

og.og:title: Your logical fallacy is ambiguity
og.og:description: You used a double meaning or ambiguity of language to mislead or misrepresent the truth.

entries.name: the-gamblers-fallacy
entries.title: the gambler's fallacy
entries.head: You said that 'runs' occur to statistically independent phenomena such as roulette wheel spins.
entries.first: Believing that 'runs' occur to statistically independent phenomena such as roulette wheel spins.
entries.description: This commonly believed fallacy can be said to have helped create an entire city in the desert of Nevada USA. Though the overall odds of a 'big run' happening may be low, each spin of the wheel is itself entirely independent from the last. So whilst there may be a very small chance that heads will come up 20 times in a row if you flip a coin, the chances of heads coming up on each individual flip remain 50/50, and aren't influenced by what happened before.
entries.example: Red had come up six times in a row on the roulette wheel, so Greg knew that it was close to certain that black would be next up. Suffering an economic form of natural selection with this thinking, he soon lost all of his savings.
entries.pageTitle: Your logical fallacy is the gambler's fallacy
entries.exampleText: Example: Red had come up six times in a row on the roulette wheel, so Greg knew that it was close to certain that black would be next up. Suffering an economic form of natural selection with this thinking, he soon lost all of his savings.

seo.title: Your logical fallacy is the gambler's fallacy
seo.description: You said that 'runs' occur to statistically independent phenomena such as roulette wheel spins.

og.og:title: Your logical fallacy is the gambler's fallacy
og.og:description: You said that 'runs' occur to statistically independent phenomena such as roulette wheel spins.

entries.name: bandwagon
entries.title: bandwagon
entries.head: You appealed to popularity or the fact that many people do something as an attempted form of validation.
entries.first: Appealing to popularity or the fact that many people do something as an attempted form of validation.
entries.description:
The flaw in this argument is that the popularity of an idea has absolutely no bearing on its validity.
If it did, then the Earth would have made itself flat for most of history to accommodate this popular belief.
entries.example: Shamus pointed a drunken finger at Sean and asked him to explain how so many people could believe in leprechauns if they're only a silly old superstition. Sean, however, had had a few too many Guinness himself and fell off his chair.
entries.pageTitle: Your logical fallacy is bandwagon
entries.exampleText: Example: Shamus pointed a drunken finger at Sean and asked him to explain how so many people could believe in leprechauns if they're only a silly old superstition. Sean, however, had had a few too many Guinness himself and fell off his chair.

seo.title: Your logical fallacy is bandwagon
seo.description: You appealed to popularity or the fact that many people do something as an attempted form of validation.

og.og:title: Your logical fallacy is bandwagon
og.og:description: You appealed to popularity or the fact that many people do something as an attempted form of validation.

entries.name: appeal-to-authority
entries.title: appeal to authority
entries.head: You said that because an authority thinks something, it must therefore be true.
entries.first: Saying that because an authority thinks something, it must therefore be true.
entries.description: It's important to note that this fallacy should not be used to dismiss the claims of experts, or scientific consensus. Appeals to authority are not valid arguments, but nor is it reasonable to disregard the claims of experts who have a demonstrated depth of knowledge unless one has a similar level of understanding and/or access to empirical evidence. However, it is entirely possible that the opinion of a person or institution of authority is wrong; therefore the authority that such a person or institution holds does not have any intrinsic bearing upon whether their claims are true or not.
entries.example: Not able to defend his position that evolution 'isn't true' Bob says that he knows a scientist who also questions evolution (and presumably isn't a primate).
entries.pageTitle: Your logical fallacy is appeal to authority
entries.exampleText: Example: Not able to defend his position that evolution 'isn't true' Bob says that he knows a scientist who also questions evolution (and presumably isn't a primate).

seo.title: Your logical fallacy is appeal to authority
seo.description: You said that because an authority thinks something, it must therefore be true.

og.og:title: Your logical fallacy is appeal to authority
og.og:description: You said that because an authority thinks something, it must therefore be true.

entries.name: composition-division
entries.title: composition/division
entries.head: You assumed that one part of something has to be applied to all, or other, parts of it; or that the whole must apply to its parts.
entries.first: Assuming that what's true about one part of something has to be applied to all, or other, parts of it.
entries.description: Often when something is true for the part it does also apply to the whole, or vice versa, but the crucial difference is whether there exists good evidence to show that this is the case. Because we observe consistencies in things, our thinking can become biased so that we presume consistency to exist where it does not.
entries.example: Daniel was a precocious child and had a liking for logic. He reasoned that atoms are invisible, and that he was made of atoms and therefore invisible too. Unfortunately, despite his thinky skills, he lost the game of hide and go seek.
entries.pageTitle: Your logical fallacy is composition/division
entries.exampleText: Example: Daniel was a precocious child and had a liking for logic. He reasoned that atoms are invisible, and that he was made of atoms and therefore invisible too. Unfortunately, despite his thinky skills, he lost the game of hide and go seek.

seo.title: Your logical fallacy is composition or division
seo.description: You assumed that one part of something has to be applied to all, or other, parts of it; or that the whole must apply to its parts.

og.og:title: Your logical fallacy is composition or division
og.og:description: You assumed that one part of something has to be applied to all, or other, parts of it; or that the whole must apply to its parts.

entries.name: no-true-scotsman
entries.title: no true scotsman
entries.head: You made what could be called an appeal to purity as a way to dismiss relevant criticisms or flaws of your argument.
entries.first: Making what could be called an appeal to purity as a way to dismiss relevant criticisms or flaws of an argument.
entries.description: In this form of faulty reasoning one's belief is rendered unfalsifiable because no matter how compelling the evidence is, one simply shifts the goalposts so that it wouldn't apply to a supposedly 'true' example. This kind of post-rationalization is a way of avoiding valid criticisms of one's argument.
entries.example: Angus declares that Scotsmen do not put sugar on their porridge, to which Lachlan points out that he is a Scotsman and puts sugar on his porridge. Furious, like a true Scot, Angus yells that no true Scotsman sugars his porridge.
entries.pageTitle: Your logical fallacy is no true scotsman
entries.exampleText: Example: Angus declares that Scotsmen do not put sugar on their porridge, to which Lachlan points out that he is a Scotsman and puts sugar on his porridge. Furious, like a true Scot, Angus yells that no true Scotsman sugars his porridge.

seo.title: Your logical fallacy is no true scotsman
seo.description: You made what could be called an appeal to purity as a way to dismiss relevant criticisms or flaws of your argument.

og.og:title: Your logical fallacy is no true scotsman
og.og:description: You made what could be called an appeal to purity as a way to dismiss relevant criticisms or flaws of your argument.

entries.name: genetic
entries.title: genetic
entries.head: You judged something as either good or bad on the basis of where it comes from, or from whom it came.
entries.first: Judging something good or bad on the basis of where it comes from, or from whom it comes.
entries.description: This fallacy avoids the argument by shifting focus onto something's or someone's origins. It's similar to an ad hominem fallacy in that it leverages existing negative perceptions to make someone's argument look bad, without actually presenting a case for why the argument itself lacks merit.
entries.example: Accused on the 6 o'clock news of corruption and taking bribes, the senator said that we should all be very wary of the things we hear in the media, because we all know how very unreliable the media can be.
entries.pageTitle: Your logical fallacy is genetic
entries.exampleText: Example: Accused on the 6 o'clock news of corruption and taking bribes, the senator said that we should all be very wary of the things we hear in the media, because we all know how very unreliable the media can be.

seo.title: Your logical fallacy is genetic
seo.description: You judged something as either good or bad on the basis of where it comes from, or from whom it came.

og.og:title: Your logical fallacy is genetic
og.og:description: You judged something as either good or bad on the basis of where it comes from, or from whom it came.

entries.name: black-or-white
entries.title: black-or-white
entries.head: You presented two alternative states as the only possibilities, when in fact more possibilities exist.
entries.first: Where two alternative states are presented as the only possibilities, when in fact more possibilities exist.
entries.description: Also known as the false dilemma, this insidious tactic has the appearance of forming a logical argument, but under closer scrutiny it becomes evident that there are more possibilities than the either/or choice that is presented. Binary, black-or-white thinking doesn't allow for the many different variables, conditions, and contexts in which there would exist more than just the two possibilities put forth. It frames the argument misleadingly and obscures rational, honest debate.
entries.example: Whilst rallying support for his plan to fundamentally undermine citizens' rights, the Supreme Leader told the people they were either on his side, or they were on the side of the enemy.
entries.pageTitle: Your logical fallacy is black-or-white
entries.exampleText: Example: Whilst rallying support for his plan to fundamentally undermine citizens' rights, the Supreme Leader told the people they were either on his side, or they were on the side of the enemy.

seo.title: Your logical fallacy is black or white
seo.description: You presented two alternative states as the only possibilities, when in fact more possibilities exist.

og.og:title: Your logical fallacy is black or white
og.og:description: You presented two alternative states as the only possibilities, when in fact more possibilities exist.

entries.name: begging-the-question
entries.title: begging the question
entries.head: You presented a circular argument in which the conclusion was included in the premise.
entries.first: A circular argument in which the conclusion is included in the premise.
entries.description: This logically incoherent argument often arises in situations where people have an assumption that is very ingrained, and therefore taken in their minds as a given. Circular reasoning is bad mostly because it's not very good.
entries.example: The word of Zorbo the Great is flawless and perfect. We know this because it says so in The Great and Infallible Book of Zorbo's Best and Most Truest Things that are Definitely True and Should Not Ever Be Questioned.
entries.pageTitle: Your logical fallacy is begging the question
entries.exampleText: Example: The word of Zorbo the Great is flawless and perfect. We know this because it says so in The Great and Infallible Book of Zorbo's Best and Most Truest Things that are Definitely True and Should Not Ever Be Questioned.

seo.title: Your logical fallacy is begging the question
seo.description: You presented a circular argument in which the conclusion was included in the premise.

og.og:title: Your logical fallacy is begging the question
og.og:description: You presented a circular argument in which the conclusion was included in the premise.

entries.name: appeal-to-nature
entries.title: appeal to nature
entries.head: You argued that because something is 'natural' it is therefore valid, justified, inevitable, good or ideal.
entries.first: Making the argument that because something is 'natural' it is therefore valid, justified, inevitable, good, or ideal.
entries.description: Many 'natural' things are also considered 'good', and this can bias our thinking; but naturalness itself doesn't make something good or bad. For instance murder could be seen as very natural, but that doesn't mean it's good or justifiable.
entries.example: The medicine man rolled into town on his bandwagon offering various natural remedies, such as very special plain water. He said that it was only natural that people should be wary of 'artificial' medicines such as antibiotics.
entries.pageTitle: Your logical fallacy is appeal to nature
entries.exampleText: Example: The medicine man rolled into town on his bandwagon offering various natural remedies, such as very special plain water. He said that it was only natural that people should be wary of 'artificial' medicines such as antibiotics.

seo.title: Your logical fallacy is appeal to nature
seo.description: You argued that because something is 'natural' it is therefore valid, justified, inevitable, good or ideal.

og.og:title: Your logical fallacy is appeal to nature
og.og:description: You argued that because something is 'natural' it is therefore valid, justified, inevitable, good or ideal.

entries.name: anecdotal
entries.title: anecdotal
entries.head: You used a personal experience or an isolated example instead of a sound argument or compelling evidence.
entries.first: Using personal experience or an isolated example instead of a valid argument, especially to dismiss statistics.
entries.description: It's often much easier for people to believe someone's testimony as opposed to understanding complex data and variation across a continuum. Quantitative scientific measures are almost always more accurate than personal perceptions and experiences, but our inclination is to believe that which is tangible to us, and/or the word of someone we trust over a more 'abstract' statistical reality.
entries.example: Jason said that that was all cool and everything, but his grandfather smoked, like, 30 cigarettes a day and lived until 97 - so don't believe everything you read about meta analyses of methodologically sound studies showing proven causal relationships.
entries.pageTitle: Your logical fallacy is anecdotal
entries.exampleText: Example: Jason said that that was all cool and everything, but his grandfather smoked, like, 30 cigarettes a day and lived until 97 - so don't believe everything you read about meta analyses of methodologically sound studies showing proven causal relationships.

seo.title: Your logical fallacy is anecdotal
seo.description: You used a personal experience or an isolated example instead of a sound argument or compelling evidence.

og.og:title: Your logical fallacy is anecdotal
og.og:description: You used a personal experience or an isolated example instead of a sound argument or compelling evidence.

entries.name: the-texas-sharpshooter
entries.title: the texas sharpshooter
entries.head: You cherry-picked a data cluster to suit your argument, or found a pattern to fit a presumption.
entries.first: Cherry-picking data clusters to suit an argument, or finding a pattern to fit a presumption.
entries.description: This 'false cause' fallacy is coined after a marksman shooting randomly at barns and then painting bullseye targets around the spot where the most bullet holes appear, making it appear as if he's a really good shot. Clusters naturally appear by chance, but don't necessarily indicate that there is a causal relationship.
entries.example: The makers of Sugarette Candy Drinks point to research showing that of the five countries where Sugarette drinks sell the most units, three of them are in the top ten healthiest countries on Earth, therefore Sugarette drinks are healthy.
entries.pageTitle: Your logical fallacy is the texas sharpshooter
entries.exampleText: Example: The makers of Sugarette Candy Drinks point to research showing that of the five countries where Sugarette drinks sell the most units, three of them are in the top ten healthiest countries on Earth, therefore Sugarette drinks are healthy.

seo.title: Your logical fallacy is the texas sharpshooter
seo.description: You cherry-picked a data cluster to suit your argument, or found a pattern to fit a presumption.

og.og:title: Your logical fallacy is the texas sharpshooter
og.og:description: You cherry-picked a data cluster to suit your argument, or found a pattern to fit a presumption.

entries.name: middle-ground
entries.title: middle ground
entries.head: You claimed that a compromise, or middle point, between two extremes must be the truth.
entries.first: Saying that a compromise, or middle point, between two extremes is the truth.
entries.description: Much of the time the truth does indeed lie between two extreme points, but this can bias our thinking: sometimes a thing is simply untrue and a compromise of it is also untrue. Half way between truth and a lie, is still a lie.
entries.example: Holly said that vaccinations caused autism in children, but her scientifically well-read friend Caleb said that this claim had been debunked and proven false. Their friend Alice offered a compromise that vaccinations must cause some autism, just not all autism.
entries.pageTitle: Your logical fallacy is middle ground
entries.exampleText: Example: Holly said that vaccinations caused autism in children, but her scientifically well-read friend Caleb said that this claim had been debunked and proven false. Their friend Alice offered a compromise that vaccinations must cause some autism, just not all autism.

seo.title: Your logical fallacy is middle ground
seo.description: You claimed that a compromise, or middle point, between two extremes must be the truth.
